722426f.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Church Street
722426f.folder: Park Row & Church Street, Manhattan, NY

722427f.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Church Street
722427f.text:
Park Row, Manhattan, is the street vertically
bisecting this photograph.
The New York Iimes building was at nos. 37-44 Park Row, with no. 44 (facing the viewer) as the
aain entrance.
The PostDffice Building (right) fronted on Mail
Street, opposite City Hall Park.
This photograph was taken between 1875 (when the newly constructed Poct 0ffice was first occupied) and 1888 (when the New York Iimes building was
raed).
722427f.folder: Park Row & Church Street, Manhattan, NY

718864f-b.title: Manhattan: Church Street - Park Place
718864f-b.text:
(1)
An aerial view of Church Street, at Barclay Strcct. The view shows Barclay Street, north side, east from and including Church Street, to, but not including Broadway, with the Woolworth Building in the background, and St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in the foreground on Barclay at the
S.E. cornor of Church Street.
April 3, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same and showing a further view northward on the east side of
Church Street, to and including Park Place.
March 5, 1934.
. Sperr.  N6 RsPR5DUCiIoNs.

718866f-a.title: Manhattan: Church Street - Barclay Street
718866f-a.text:
Church Street, east side, south from Barclay Street, (left), showing St. Peters Roman Chatholic Church (1.v.), the Underwood Building and the old "El' tracks. The latter, at this date, are under denolition. To the right appears the open space caused by
St. Pauls Cemetery.
March 4, 1939
C;ift of W. A . Lucas
718866f-a.folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY

718867f-a.title: Manhattan: Church Street - Barclay Street
718867f-a.text:
Church Street, north from Barclay Street, showing the Sixth Avenue "El" photographed against buildings on the east side of this thoroughfare and its Park Place station prior to demolition. View No. 3, being one month later, shows the razing of this structure underway. Note that this thoroughfare has been widened, a slice having been taken off of the west side of same. This occurred during subway construction recently. The property at the left, consisting of 2 scuare blocks, are holdings of Columbia University. At the northern edge of this, the "El" turns westward thru Murray Street.
January 17, 1939
Views 1 and 2
View 3: February 18, 1939
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRV9DUCTIONS (1 and 2)
Cnift of W. A. Lucas
718867f-a.folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY

View No. 3, being one month later, shows the razing of this structure underway. Note that this thoroughfare has been widened, a slice having been taken off of the west side of same. This occurred during subway construction recently. The property at the left, consisting of 2 scuare blocks, are holdings of Columbia University. View No. 3, being one month later, shows the razing of this structure underway. Note that this thoroughfare has been widened, a slice having been taken off of the west side of same. This occurred during subway construction recently. The property at the left, consisting of 2 scuare blocks, are holdings of Columbia University. At the northern edge of this, the "El" turns westward thru Murray Street.

718867f-b.folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY

718868f-a.title: Manhattan: Church Street - Barclay Street
718868f-a.text:
Church Street, east side, north from Barclay Street. At the right is a portion of St. Peters Roman Catholic Church. Note the width of thi thoroughfare and the absence of the old "El" structure. The first is attributable to the Eighth Avenue subway constructuon in 1V3o, and the latter to the efforts of Mayor LaGuardia
towards transportation unification.
July 17, 1939
L. Sperr
718868f-a.folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY

718869f-a.title: Manhattan: Church Street - Barclay Street
718869f-a.text:
Church Street, west side, north from Barclay Street. En the center is Park Place, Uevoid of its "El" station. The tracks, pillars, etc will shortly follow. Note the additional width on the far side of this thoroughfare. The result of late subway
construction. being thereby apparent.
March 4, 1939
Gift of W . A. Lucas
718869f-a.folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY

(1)
Church Street, west side, south from and including Barclay, to E1 ' Fulton Streets. Prominent buildings shewn, are the Hudson and Manhattan R.R. Terminal Buildings.
June 5, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)

the site of the new Post Office.
November 25, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, slightly later.
May 11, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

718870f-a.title: Manhattan: Church Street - Barclay Street
718870f-a.text:
Church Street, north from Barclay Stret (foreground, street 1evel not shown), showing the Sixth Avenue "El" lines, it's Park Place station, the westward bend at Murray Street, and the street widening-Eighth Avenue subway construction. The later necessitated a 50 foot slice off of the westerly side of this thoroughfare, extending to Canal Street. At that point (center of view 2 and to the left of view 1) a pears the New York Telephone Building
in two forms, before and after reconstruction.
View 1: June 4, 1929
View 2: March 27, 1935
P. L. Sperr
718870f-a.folder: Church Street & Barclay Street, Manhattan, NY
